title: Eurotransplant Kidney Allocation Simulations

source.description:
Collect demographic data from
Eurotransplant Annual Report page
  • age distribution per country
  • donor blood group distribution per country
  • recipient blood group distribution per country on the initial waiting list
  • number of DBD donors per country
  • number of DCD donors per country
  • DBD/DCD acceptance matrix, i.e. which country accepts which donor types
  • number of organ donors involved in later transplantation
  • number of used donor kidneys per donor per country
  • PRA group distribution per country
  • probability of transplant center rejecting an organ offer per HLA match grade, in our case 0.1 for all situations
  • patients removed from the waiting list per country, subtracted by the ETKAS transplanted patients per country
  • urgency distribution per country
  • country distribution of patients on the waiting list, for bootstrapping only
  • country distribution of patients registered to the waiting list
  • waiting time distribution of patients on the waiting list per country, for bootstrapping only
  • waiting time distribution of patients registered to the waiting list per country
Iterate over 3650 days, i.e. 10 years each having 365 days

Create virtual phenotypes by randomly picking two haplotypes
  • Select population, 2011 EURCAU in our case
  • considering weight in random selection
  • exclude phenotypes with identical haplotype
  • add translation into serological equivalents

Download
NMDP haplotype frequency dataset

Download
HLA Matchmaker
, extract eplet definitions as CSV

Download rel-dna-ser file containing serological equivalents for alleles
WMDA
Allocate donor to current waiting list
Generate virtual initial waiting list

Append
PIRCHE Risk Profile
median to virtual phenotypes
    via REST API
pick random phenotype from virtual population
randomly select patient country, considering country distributions on waiting list
randomly select patient age range based on country
randomly select waiting time range based on country with uniform distribution within waiting time range
randomly select urgency based on country
randomly select PRA range based on country with uniform distribution within PRA range, used as target PRA

Iteratively add unacceptable alleles randomly based on allele frequency
Translate current unacceptable alleles to eplets with respect to self-eplets
calculate current PRA based on eplets in virtual population
repeat steps until current cPRA is target PRA +- 4 %
discard random unacceptable alleles if PRA exceeds threshold or if eplets matching with self-eplets

translate unacceptable alleles to unacceptable antigens
allele-specific antibodies are not translated into an unacceptable but are kept for later crossmatching
Generate donor
Randomly select donor type based on distributions, i.e. DBD/DCD
Randomly select donor country based on distributions
Randomly select donor blood group based on distributions
Randomly decide number of kidneys harvested from this donor
Randomly select number of donors available "today"
Iterate over donors
Draw random phenotype from virtual population without replacement
Randomly deregister patients from the waiting list according to conditional probability
Filter waiting list by donor acceptance in country
Filter waiting list by blood group identity
Filter waiting list by unacceptable mismatches
Add points for waiting time, 0.091/d

Calculate
PIRCHE scores
for waiting list and donor, via REST API
Add points for country balance, 10 * [maxCountryBalance - countryBalance]
Add 100 pediatric bonus points, multiply match points by 2 for pediatric patients
Add 300 points if donor and recipient country match
Add 500 HU bonus points, match points are ignored in this case

Add 100 mismatch probability points:
mmp = 100 \times \left( 1 - \left [bloodgroupFrequency * \left (1 - relativePRA \right ) \times \left[1 - min \left[1, \frac {PIRCHE-II-Risk-Profile-median} {200}\right ] \right] \right] \right)^{20}

Add 400 points based on matching:
matching = 400 * max \left(-0.0111 * \left [ 1 + PIRCHE-II-Score \right ], 0 \right )
Priority if PIRCHE-II score is below 9
Evaluate homozygous loci, per homozygosity add 1 to homozygosity score

For fully homozygous donors: sort descending by priority, homozygosity score and points
For other donors: sort descending by priority and points
Select patients from the top of the ordered waiting list for each harvested kidney of current donor, randomly reject patient based on rejection probability
Crossmatch recipient and donor, i.e. exclude if recipient unacceptable alleles contain donor allele
Remove selected recipients from the waiting list
Update country balance according to selected patients' country of origin and donor country
Evolve waiting list by increasing waiting time for all patients
Register new patients to the waiting list, see step #7

description:
Background:
The EuroTransplant Kidney Allocation System (ETKAS) aims at allocating organs to patients on the waiting list fairly whilst optimizing HLA match grades. ETKAS currently considers the number of HLA-A/-B/-DR mismatches. Evidently, epitope matching is biologically and clinically more relevant. We here executed ETKAS-based computer simulations to evaluate the impact of epitope matching on allocation and compared the strategies. 
Methods:
A virtual population of 400,000 individuals was generated using the National Marrow Donor Program (NMDP) haplotype frequency dataset of 2011. Using this population, a waiting list of 10,400 patients was constructed and maintained during simulation, matching the 2015 Eurotransplant Annual Report characteristics. Unacceptable antigens were assigned randomly relative to their frequency using HLAMatchmaker. Over 22,600 kidneys were allocated in 10 years in triplicate using Markov Chain Monte Carlo simulations on 32-CPU-core cloud-computing instances. T-cell epitopes were calculated using the www.pirche.com portal. Waiting list effects were evaluated against ETKAS for five epitope matching scenarios. 
Results:
Baseline simulations of ETKAS slightly overestimated reported average HLA match grades. The best-balanced scenario maintained prioritisation of HLA A-B-DR fully matched donors while replacing the HLA match grade by PIRCHE-II score and exchanging the HLA mismatch probability (MMP) by epitope MMP. This setup showed no considerable impact on kidney exchange rates and waiting time. PIRCHE-II scores improved, whereas the average HLA match grade diminishes slightly, yet leading to an improved estimated graft survival. 
Conclusions:
We conclude that epitope-based matching in deceased donor kidney allocation is feasible while maintaining equal balances on the waiting list.
